rev.comment: Using a fair use image as a teeny little 12px icon fails [[WP:NFCC]]

â
[[File:Prince logo.svg|12px]] is the fourteenth album by American recording artist [[Prince (musician)|Prince]], released October 13, 1992 on [[Paisley Park Records|Paisley Park]] and [[Warner Bros. Records]].<ref name=Discogs>[http://www.discogs.com/artist/Prince+%26+The+New+Power+Generation Prince & The New Power Generation Discography]. [[Discogs]]. Retrieved on 2009-04-15.</ref> Due to its official title being an unpronounceable symbol, which Prince later adopted as his name, the album has been referred to as the '''''Love Symbol Album''''', or simply '''''Symbol'''''. It is Prince's second album to feature his backing group, [[The New Power Generation]], which received co-billing for the release. The album contains elements of musical styles including [[funk]], [[Contemporary R&B|R&B]], [[Hip hop music|hip hop]], [[jazz]], [[reggae]], and [[synthpop]].<ref>[http://www.discogs.com/Prince-The-New-Power-Generation-Untitled-Symbol/release/1662802 Untitled (Symbol) (US CD, Album)]. Discogs. Retrieved on 2009-04-16.</ref>
+
The fourteenth album by American recording artist [[Prince (musician)|Prince]] was released October 13, 1992 on [[Paisley Park Records|Paisley Park]] and [[Warner Bros. Records]].<ref name=Discogs>[http://www.discogs.com/artist/Prince+%26+The+New+Power+Generation Prince & The New Power Generation Discography]. [[Discogs]]. Retrieved on 2009-04-15.</ref> Due to its official title being the unpronounceable symbol '''''O(+>''''', which Prince later adopted as his name, the album has been referred to as the '''''Love Symbol Album''''', or simply '''''Symbol'''''. It is Prince's second album to feature his backing group, [[The New Power Generation]], which received co-billing for the release. The album contains elements of musical styles including [[funk]], [[Contemporary R&B|R&B]], [[Hip hop music|hip hop]], [[jazz]], [[reggae]], and [[synthpop]].<ref>[http://www.discogs.com/Prince-The-New-Power-Generation-Untitled-Symbol/release/1662802 Untitled (Symbol) (US CD, Album)]. Discogs. Retrieved on 2009-04-16.</ref>
The album's first two singles, "[[My Name Is Prince]]" and "[[Sexy MF]]", were only minor hits on the US pop charts, though both made top ten in the UK. Conversely, the third single, "[[7 (song)|7]]", was relatively unsuccessful in the UK, but was a top ten hit in the US. The album was originally conceived as a "fantasy rock soap opera" with various spoken [[segue]]s throughout.<ref>{{Cite news | last =Willman| first = Chris| coauthors = | title = Prince's Latest Fleshed-Out Fantasy| newspaper = [[Los Angeles Times]] | location =| pages = | language = | publisher = | date = October 11, 1992| url = http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/latimes/access/61717569.html?dids=61717569:61717569&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Oct+11%2C+1992&author=CHRIS+WILLMAN&pub=Los+Angeles+Times+(pre-1997+Fulltext)&desc=Prince's+Latest+Fleshed-Out+Fantasy+**+PRINCE+%26+THE+N.P.G.+%22(genders+merging+symbol)+%22+Paisley+Park%2FWarner+Bros.&pqatl=google| accessdate = }}</ref> However, in a last-minute attempt to add an additional song, most of the segues had to be cut for album length. The few that remained were somewhat confusing in context. The album also debuts [[Mayte Garcia]], who plays a part in the album's storyline and would become Prince's wife in 1996.
The album's first two singles, "[[My Name Is Prince]]" and "[[Sexy MF]]", were only minor hits on the US pop charts, though both made top ten in the UK. Conversely, the third single, "[[7 (song)|7]]", was relatively unsuccessful in the UK, but was a top ten hit in the US. The album was originally conceived as a "fantasy rock soap opera" with various spoken [[segue]]s throughout.<ref>{{Cite news | last =Willman| first = Chris| coauthors = | title = Prince's Latest Fleshed-Out Fantasy| newspaper = [[Los Angeles Times]] | location =| pages = | language = | publisher = | date = October 11, 1992| url = http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/latimes/access/61717569.html?dids=61717569:61717569&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Oct+11%2C+1992&author=CHRIS+WILLMAN&pub=Los+Angeles+Times+(pre-1997+Fulltext)&desc=Prince's+Latest+Fleshed-Out+Fantasy+**+PRINCE+%26+THE+N.P.G.+%22(genders+merging+symbol)+%22+Paisley+Park%2FWarner+Bros.&pqatl=google| accessdate = }}</ref> However, in a last-minute attempt to add an additional song, most of the segues had to be cut for album length. The few that remained were somewhat confusing in context. The album also debuts [[Mayte Garcia]], who plays a part in the album's storyline and would become Prince's wife in 1996.
